AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: ashy-gray, more or less rough and flaky

Chinkapin Oak, also known as Chestnut Oak, is an oak that is seldom available due to transplanting difficulties. However, small seedlings can be successfully established. The dark green lustrous leaves turn yellow to orangish in fall. Massive trees occur in dry, limestone-based soil as well as rich bottomlands. If native in an area, the tree should be protected and enjoyed. It is a fine park or large-area tree.
Chinkapin Oak trees are located north of Tau Center on the West Campus and northeast of Darrell Krueger Library on the Main Campus.
unisexual with male flowers in slender, pendulous catkins 1-3" long from buds on the previous year's branchlets and female flowers on current year's branchlets, in May, wind pollinated
acorn, oval 3/4-1" long, enclosed about 1/2 by thin cap with small scales, maturing the first year
simple, alternate, deciduous, oblong, 4-6", usually rounded at the base, coarsely toothed, lustrous dark yellow-green above, whitish beneath
grows in high, dry uplands on calcareous and coarse textured soil, and was found in Houston County at one time, both fire- and drought-tolerant
